text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because most of what we’re looking for is how you feel. Oh, I’m having nausea. No. I’m not having nausea. Oh, this was a cakewalk. Oh, my fingers aren’t numb. Huh, my counts, huh, you know, are fine. Things that we’re going to be testing. So then we can sort of compare what blood test and symptoms are for those who actually get the vitamin C versus those who don’t. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have a fifty-fifty chance that you’re going to get the real stuff. Huh, you know, there is some flexibility. They want you here at least twice a week. But you know, if you’re going to go on holiday or something, you know, we can switch it. Huh, so far we know that giving high doses of vitamin C is safe. Huh, we haven’t seen many real extra side effects. But we don’t know the end of the answer. Does it help with side effects? Does it help activity? Or is there no difference? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so you would be potentially eligible for that. Huh, if you do a clinical trial, it does slow down a little bit when we get started. Okay? Huh, because we would first want to check your insurance company that they will pay for the clinical trial. You’re not on Medicare yet. You’re not sixty-five. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so we’d have to check with your insurance. Do they cover clinical trials, if you’re interested? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, if they are. Then in the forms that we give them and give you, it tells them, huh, what they’re paying for, and it tells you what we’re going to pay for. So definitely the dummy vitamin C or the real vitamin C we pay for because that’s experimental. Your insurance company may have to pay for the time in the chair to get the medicine. Okay? Huh, if you have to pay five dollars every time you come into this building, huh, this study could cost you more money because you’re here more often. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, but if you don’t have a copay for visits, then that’s, you know. So there are some hidden costs. You know? If you’re coming in more often and you have to pay for parking and, you know, those sorts of things, huh, we do have the ability for some of our studies to pay for your parking. We do. Or even if you need a ride here, there’s a group of, do you live in the city? Patient: Um hum.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s in a location which is classical and typical for where prostate cancer can typically spread. Patient: Okay then that’s - where is it? Where did you say it went? Doctor: I have to remind myself which side it’s on. It’s on the abdominal - it’s in the abdomen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s too deep to feel, so it’s internal, inside the abdomen. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s on the uh - it’s called the left iliac lymph node. So the left iliac lymph node is basically um where the blood vessel called the aorta splits up into the two iliac arteries. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then there are lymph nodes on each side. So I would say if I, if I could go through your abdomen like three inches, I’d hit it; it’s on the left side. Patient: Now I did have uh a gist and I had that surgery July the thirteenth. I remember that was in the stomach. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So is it in somewhere in comparison…? text: Family Member: everyone gets chemo. Which is great for me, you’re like wow, I guess it’s great for you but you know we all have mixed feelings a little bit. I get that. Patient: Right. Doctor: The second study is chemotherapy plus an immunotherapy versus chemotherapy. So, docetaxel plus immunotherapy versus docetaxel. So, you know, either one of those is doable. Again, if you had stuff outside of bone that’s probably what we should do. Hi, oh, for the opioids, Okay, for your pain, yeah. So, then the other part is what if you’re just bone. So, let’s say we do this and you’re just in your bones, no lymph nodes, liver, nothing, it’s clean then I think we should consider radium or Xofigo. Family Member: Together with the docetaxel? Doctor: No, just radium. So, there it’s um to combine with anything else is not standard of care and we don’t have our trial up yet with radium plus something. But, at this moment standard of care is just monthly radium for six months and that improves your survival span. So does chemotherapy but radium you can only give if it’s just in bone. So, if you have it like in the liver or whatever kind of like when we first started Patient: Um hum. Doctor: it was like oh, no you kind of had these bits and pieces, Patient: Right. Doctor: one, your insurance won’t approve it and number two it’s the wrong treatment. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, if that’s sort of gone and nowhere to be found on this CAT scan then I think radium is it. Now, radium does two things. One is that it helps you live longer but also helps with pain so those people who are, you know, whether you’re taking a Tylenol over-the-counter or you’re taking actual narcotics that should improve. Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
